Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Multiscale Model-Data Fusion for Structural Health Monitoring of Fracture Critical Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Descripition of the Project's Significance

This Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant (BRIGE) provides funding to develop a framework for structural health monitoring, diagnosis and prognosis of fracture critical structures. Fracture critical structures are those in which the failure of a single component can generate the failure of the complete system or a large portion of it. Recent catastrophic failures of these types of structures, especially bridges, have highlighted the need for a new and transformative approach to the problem. This project will develop the computational and data analysis tools necessary to continuously monitor fracture critical structures and help prevent such failures.

Technical Description of the Project

The multiscale model-data fusion framework relies on a series of models, which represent the mechanical behavior of the structure at various scales of interest, and vibration measurements of local and global structural response. The project will develop algorithms capable of optimally combining the predictive capabilities of multiscale finite element models and sensor measurements, to reconstruct in real-time the complete response of the structure. The reconstructed response allows assessment of the current state of cumulative fatigue damage throughout the structure, thus anticipating potential damage before it reaches a critical level. The estimated damage condition, with its associated uncertainty is projected into the future and an estimate of the structural reliability can be obtained. The research involves development of computational algorithms, laboratory experiments and field validation using real data from an instrumented operational bridge in Vermont. The methods developed in this project will aide engineers to perform smarter early diagnosis and predictive maintenance of a multitude of conventional and non-conventional structural systems spanning civil, mechanical, biomedical and electrical applications. This project will also provide an opportunity to foster collaborations and potential applications of the research idea into medical diagnosis.

Activities to Broaden the Participation of Underrepresented Groups in Engineering

Funding from this project will enable the principal investigator to recruit under-represented minorities into engineering education, research and mentoring. It will also allow him to undertake K-12 activities aimed at educating students about engineering, diversity and its critical importance in our society. This project will facilitate collaborations with existing initiatives at the University of Vermont aimed at recruiting undergraduate and graduate students, especially female and Latinos interested in pursuing careers in engineering. The PI will work with various student groups, such as the chapters of the Society of Women Engineers and American Society of Civil Engineers, which have volunteered to take part in sharing the engineering experience with K-12 students. These groups will join the PI in visiting local schools and hosting recruiting and educational activities at the university. The educational component of the project involves the development of a hands-on structural engineering lab designed to help students appreciate the role of models and sensors in understanding the behavior of structures. The PI will also develop a multidisciplinary course titled Reliability of Engineering System aimed at graduate students from all engineering disciplines. This course will incorporate data and findings from the research project into the course learning objectives.

This research has been funded through the Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grants in Engineering solicitation, which is part of the Broadening Participation in Engineering Program of the Engineering Education and Centers Division.

The research is also funded through the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), which is part of the Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nation’s infrastructure is aging and repairing every single infrastructure component that is not in ideal condition is impractical. The situation requires advanced technologies capable of monitoring and predicting which infrastructure elements require immediate intervention, and which ones can continue to operate safely (diagnosis), and for how long (prognosis). The overall objective of this research project is to process and interpret operational vibration measurements and combine them with multiscale models to perform diagnosis and prognosis of fracture critical structures subjected to cumulative load-induced damage such as fatigue. Fracture critical structures are those in which the failure of a single component can produce the failure of the complete structure or of a large portion of it. Recent failures of these type of structures, especially bridges, have highlighted the inefficacy of existing structural health monitoring (SHM) paradigms based on “damage” detection and the need to develop new methods that allow engineers to track the accumulation of invisible damage in real-time.

This project involved theoretical developments in the area of model-data fusion, uncertainty quantification, multi-scale modeling and fatigue damage mechanics. The project also involved laboratory testing of prototype structures and field-testing using an operational and instrumented bridge structure.

The main conclusions from this project are as follows:

1. It is not sufficient to simply try to detect the presence of damage (such as a crack) in a fracture critical structure. By the time we can reliably detect the presence of a crack, the structure will be too close to failure for the detection to be useful. Therefore, the findings from this project point to the importance of anticipating or prognosticating damage as opposed to detecting it after it takes place.

2. The project developed a probabilistic methodology to quantify the degree of fatigue damage accumulation throughout the complete domain of a structure such as a building or bridge. The methodology optimally combines global and(or) local measurements such as acceleration or strain with a finite element model of the structure in order to perform stress/strain estimation throughout the complete structure. This will have an impact on the way engineers instrument structures. The project has shown that with a relatively small number of sensors one can monitor larger domains.

3. An efficient numerical method was developed to integrate stress/strain estimation uncertainty into fatigue damage uncertainty. This will help engineers to determine to what precision stress and strain time histories need to be estimated in order to estimate fatigue damage to any level of accuracy.

In summary, the results from this research will allow engineers to monitor in real-time the true reliability of a fracture critical structure. This capability is exactly what is needed to perform real-time probabilistic damage monitoring, especially in fatigue, where damage accumulates without significant degradation of stiffness, and detection using conventional “damage” detection approaches is not possible until cracks have grown to an extent where the strength has dropped dramatically and failure is practically imminent. The proposed methodology is in contrast with the traditional approach for fatigue monitoring which relies on local strain measurements of previously assumed critical locations.  In contrast, by using model-data fusion, the proposed approach enables early diagnosis with minimal instrumentation. This results in increased operational reliability with reduced operational costs.

This project partially funded the studies of two PhD student and several undergraduate researchers. Funding from this project enabled the principal investigator to engage in outreach activities for K-12 students involving classroom visits, , hands-on learning, experiments, as well as public lectures.
